snippet: Damage may be present even in the absence of obvious abnormalities like small heads, and the virus may go on replicating in babies’ brains well after birth, studies found....
abstract: Studies published in The Journal of the American Medical Assn, The New England Journal of Medicine and CDC publication Emerging Infectious Diseases conclude babies born to Zika-infected mothers are highly likely to have brain damage, even in absence of obvious physical deformity, and virus may continue replicating in their brains well after birth; studies differ as to percentage of babies adversely affected by disease.

byline.original: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. and PAM BELLUCK

lead_paragraph: Damage may be present even in the absence of obvious abnormalities like small heads, and the virus may go on replicating in babies’ brains well after birth, studies found.

headline.main: Extensive Brain Defects Seen in Babies of Mothers With Zika
headline.print_headline: Extensive Brain Defects Seen in Babies of Mothers With Zika

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Journal of the American Medical Assn
